articles.headline: ‘Dune: Part Two’ Gives Sci-Fi-Obsessed Silicon Valley a Reason to Party
articles.snippet: In a season of layoffs and cutbacks, techies seized on the second installment of the Denis Villeneuve-directed science-fiction epic by taking over movie theaters.
articles.abstract: In a season of layoffs and cutbacks, techies seized on the second installment of the Denis Villeneuve-directed science-fiction epic by taking over movie theaters.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a top-floor atrium in downtown San Francisco on Thursday evening, tech workers from Google, Slack, X and Mozilla mingled next to a pair of cardboard cutouts of Timothée Chalamet and Zendaya.

articles.headline: Google Settles Smaller Lawsuits as It Prepares for More Antitrust Fights
articles.snippet: The tech giant has recently spent more than $1 billion to resolve several legal claims as more battles with the Justice Department loom.
articles.abstract: The tech giant has recently spent more than $1 billion to resolve several legal claims as more battles with the Justice Department loom.
articles.lead_paragraph: In December, Google spent $700 million to resolve states’ claims that its Play Store had strong-armed app makers into high fees and tough terms. About six weeks after that, Google paid $350 million to end a lawsuit accusing it of improperly sharing users’ private information.

articles.headline: Newly Released Messages Detail Roots of the ‘Fake Electors’ Scheme
articles.snippet: Emails and texts unearthed in a lawsuit show how key figures intended their plan to create a “cloud of confusion” to help keep Donald Trump in office after his 2020 election loss.
articles.abstract: Emails and texts unearthed in a lawsuit show how key figures intended their plan to create a “cloud of confusion” to help keep Donald Trump in office after his 2020 election loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just five days after Election Day in 2020, a conservative lawyer named Kenneth Chesebro emailed a former judge who was working for the Trump campaign in Wisconsin, James R. Troupis, pitching an idea for how to overturn the results.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: U.N. Team Finds Grounds to Support Reports of Sexual Violence in Hamas Attack
articles.snippet: The United Nations experts also said that they had “clear and convincing information” that hostages seized in Israel on Oct. 7 had been sexually abused in Gaza, and that they had looked into reports of abuse of Palestinians in Israeli detention.
articles.abstract: The United Nations experts also said that they had “clear and convincing information” that hostages seized in Israel on Oct. 7 had been sexually abused in Gaza, and that they had looked into reports of abuse of Palestinians in Israeli detention.
articles.lead_paragraph: A United Nations report released on Monday found signs that sexual violence was committed in multiple locations during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks on Israel and said that some hostages being held in the Gaza Strip had also been subjected to rape and sexual torture.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: China Sets Robust Economic Growth Goal but No Big Stimulus
articles.snippet: Premier Li Qiang targets growth of about 5 percent this year but signals continued reluctance to use deficit spending for economic stimulus.
articles.abstract: Premier Li Qiang targets growth of about 5 percent this year but signals continued reluctance to use deficit spending for economic stimulus.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s top leaders set an ambitious goal for economic growth in 2024 as they tried to bolster conviction in an economy facing its biggest challenges in decades.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher, Alexandra Stevenson and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Shift in Russian Tactics Intensifies Air War in Ukraine
articles.snippet: Moscow’s recent gains in the east have been aided by more aggressive air support on the front lines. But that also has helped Ukraine shoot down enemy planes in the past two weeks.
articles.abstract: Moscow’s recent gains in the east have been aided by more aggressive air support on the front lines. But that also has helped Ukraine shoot down enemy planes in the past two weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Ukraine war has been fought largely on the ground in the past two years, with troops often locked in back-and-forth battles with heavy artillery and drone support. The countries’ air forces have played second fiddle because of Ukraine’s limited fleet of planes and Russia’s inability to gain the air supremacy it once expected.

articles.headline: Do Americans Have a ‘Collective Amnesia’ About Donald Trump?
articles.snippet: It’s only been three years, but memories of Mr. Trump’s presidency have faded and changed fast.
articles.abstract: It’s only been three years, but memories of Mr. Trump’s presidency have faded and changed fast.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not all that long ago, many Americans committed hours a day to tracking then-President Donald J. Trump’s every move. And then, sometime after the riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and before his first indictment, they largely stopped.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: ‘Barbie’ Ruled the Box Office, but 2023 Was Tough for Women in Hollywood
articles.snippet: The number of top films with actresses in leading roles was the lowest in a decade, and women have been joining the film academy at a considerably slower rate.
articles.abstract: The number of top films with actresses in leading roles was the lowest in a decade, and women have been joining the film academy at a considerably slower rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Greta Gerwig did not receive an Oscar nomination last month for best director for “Barbie,” despite the film’s nod for best picture and its status as a global box office phenomenon, the news revived scrutiny over gender diversity among the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences’ membership.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling and Ella Koeze

articles.headline: Bank Runs Spooked Regulators. Now a Clampdown Is Coming.
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials and other bank regulators could roll out a new proposal this spring to ward off a repeat of 2023’s banking turmoil.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials and other bank regulators could roll out a new proposal this spring to ward off a repeat of 2023’s banking turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: One year after a series of bank runs threatened the financial system, government officials are preparing to unveil a regulatory response aimed at preventing future meltdowns.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Rob Copeland

articles.headline: Brighter Economic Mood Isn’t Translating Into Support for Biden
articles.snippet: Voters feel slightly better about the economy as inflation recedes, but partisan divides remain deep, a Times/Siena poll found.
articles.abstract: Voters feel slightly better about the economy as inflation recedes, but partisan divides remain deep, a Times/Siena poll found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eight months before the election, Americans feel slightly better about the state of the economy as inflation recedes and the labor market remains stable, but President Biden doesn’t appear to be benefiting.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman, Lydia DePillis and Christine Zhang

articles.headline: Egyptians Are Buying and Selling Gold Just to Stay Afloat
articles.snippet: Clamor for the precious metal is growing as the buying power of the country’s currency plunges in value against the dollar, and inflation eats away at savings.
articles.abstract: Clamor for the precious metal is growing as the buying power of the country’s currency plunges in value against the dollar, and inflation eats away at savings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside the wood-paneled shop in Cairo’s famed Khan el-Khalili market, the price of gold was slumping fast, and Rania Hussein was feeling the future slip through her fingers.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan

articles.headline: Bitcoin Hits Record High, Completing a Stunning Comeback
articles.snippet: Bitcoin’s price surged above $69,000, breaking the record the digital currency set in November 2021 when the crypto industry was booming.
articles.abstract: Bitcoin’s price surged above $69,000, breaking the record the digital currency set in November 2021 when the crypto industry was booming.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bitcoin hit a record high of more than $69,000 on Tuesday, capping a remarkable comeback for the volatile cryptocurrency after its value plunged in 2022 amid a market meltdown.
